metadata.synopsis: Filmmaker Bill Fields (W.C. Fields) and his lovely niece, Gloria (Gloria Jean), are determined to sell a script to a producer (Franklin Pangborn). As they read the story, it comes to life, and Bill and Gloria are traveling by airplane. They fall out of the plane and land in the mansion of a strange woman, Mrs. Hemogloben (Margaret Dumont) and her equally strange daughter, Ouilotta (Susan Miller). Battling his rival (Leon Errol) and a love-sick gorilla, Bill makes it back to civilization.

reviews: Fields is typically great. Unfortunately, a lot of the picture is handed over to 15-year-old singing star Gloria Jean and her tepid musical numbers.
The movie has many solid laughs, and Fields fans will definitely want to see it.
Fields has spent most of his adult life battling babies, dogs, censors, producers, directors, the world in general. From the shape of his latest picture, it is apparent that he has Universal licked.
Nearly brilliant, nearly surreal, mostly funny
Classic Fields! No story really, just a series of vignettes, but it has you rolling on the floor.
one of the many reasons Fields is still acclaimed as a comic genius
Never Give a Sucker an Even Break (1941) is a tour de force of W.C. Fields off-beat humor, double-takes, and priceless lines and sketches.
